citeinfo.origin: Gerald Sanger, University of Washington, Department of Oceanography, Seattle, Washington 98105.
citeinfo.title: Checklist for Bird Observations from the Eastern North Pacific Ocean, 1955 - 1967

abstract.p: In August of 1955, oceanographers of the University of Washington, department of Oceanography, started a continuing policy of recording sightings of birds seen during research cruises in the Eastern North Pacific Ocean. The cruises were mostly off Washington and Oregon, between the coast and South as San Diego and some went north into the Gulf of Alaska or westward along the Aleutian Islands.

For the most part, these observations have been unpublished. The report lists areas and dates of cruises on which bird observations were recorded. The original observation logs are on file at the Data Processing Section, Department of Oceanography, University of Washington.

[Reference: Sanger, Gerald A. Checklist for Bird Observations from the Eastern North Pacific Ocean, 1955 - 1967. The Murrelet, May-August, 1972 (53-2) pp. 16-21] A copy of the reprint is available at the NOAA Seattle NMML Library.

In addition, this literature was collected as part of a metadatabase that represents one or more nearshore resources (from physical attributes such as water and air, to birds and mammals). Each entry is viewable in three formats, 1) a geospatial explicit format (ArcView 3.3) named GIS ArcView 3.3 Near GEM project, 2) a spreadsheet format (Excel 2002 and within ArcView) named GEM Nearshore Metadata Set, and 3) a ProCite database named GEM Nearshore Metadata References, which consists of references included in 1 and 2 above. The ProCite database record number corresponds to the Excel Procite Number. Reference Procite #866 for this literature's metadata.
The metadata are maintained in digital format (ArcView 3.3, Excel 2002, and Procite) and are available from the Alaska Science Center, USGS in Anchorage, Alaska.

For a detailed description of the three databases and the project, see "Bodkin, J. L., and T. Dean. 2003. Alternative Sampling Designs for Nearshore Monitoring (Gulf Ecosystem Monitoring and Research Project G-030687), US Geological Survey, Alaska Science Center, Anchorage, Alaska." available on-line at http://www.evostc.state.ak.us/pdf/GEM_final_reports/030687.pdf.

descript.purpose: To note the existence of the observations and to briefly summarize the occurrence and distribution of the species seen.

distinfo.distliab: While every effort has been made to ensure that these data are accurate and reliable within the limits of the current state of the art, NOAA cannot assume liability for any damages caused by any errors or omissions in the data, nor as a result of the failure of the data to function on a particular system.
